text: Last orders please. Close up on the face of a MAN. He draws on his cigarette. WOMAN’S VOICE (0.S.) Shaun? SHAUN stares blankly into space.
Yeah... WOMAN'S VOICE (CONT’D) Do you see what I’m saying?
Yeah, totally. We reveal that SHAUN is sitting with a woman, LIZ. They a both in their late twenties. LIZ looks slightly concerned SHAUN looks slightly confused. They are having a drink.
You shouldn’t feel so responsible.
Yeah...
I know he’s your best friend but you do live with him.
I know...
It’s not that I don’t like Ed. (speaks off to her right) Ed, it’s not that I don’t like you.
S’alright. We reveal ED right next to them, playing a horror themed FRUIT MACHINE which bleeps spooky electronic noises. He i his late twenties and slightly overweight.  A beat.
It'd just be nice if we could-
(hits the fruit machine) Fuck!
-spend a bit more time together-
Bollocks!
-just the two of us-
Cock it!
We have a laugh don’t we?
Yeah... SHAUN and LIZ smile, sharing some private joke. SHAUN relaxes, momentarily off the hook. But...
But with Ed always here, it’s no wonder I end up bringing my flatmates out. Then that only exacerbates things.
What do you mean?
Well, you guys hardly get on do you?
No, what does exacerbate mean?
It means ‘to make things worse’.
Oh right. Look, it’s not that I don’t like David and Di. (speaks off to his right) (MORE )
Guys, it’s not that I don’t like you...
That’s alright. That’s alright. We reveal DAVID and DIANNE, sitting next to LIZ. Both in their late twenties, DAVID is trendy but straight-laced, is colourful and chirpy. They hold hands.
And it’s not that I don’t want to spend time with you because I do. It’s just, Ed doesn’t really have too many friends-
Can I get any of you cunts a drink? SHAUN closes his eyes.
Anybody?
No thanks. No thanks.
I’m fine thanks, Ed.
Pint Shaun? SHAUN nods. ED holds out his palm to SHAUN, who sighs and reluctantly hands him a fiver. Meanwhile, DAVID steps in.

I know friends are important Shaun, but you've got to set aside quality time for just the two of you. I know I would, if I was Lizzy’s boyfriend. DAVID looks at LIZ with affection, as DIANNE chips in.
Or get out more. Daffs is always taking me out to see his listed buildings, I’m always dragging him to the theatre.
I’m not so hot on theatre.
I took my students to see this great new play about incest. Very cool. Lots of swearing.
He’s not so hot on theatre.
Well, how about a nice meal? You could go to that restaurant me and Daffs go to. The place that does all the fish. It’s your anniversary soon isn’t it?
It was last week.
Oh, so did you do anything special?
We came here.
Yeah, but that was just me and you.
And Ed.
He wasn’t with us.
He was sitting at the bar. It’s not the same.
Shauny, hog lumps! A packet of Pork Scratchings hits SHAUN square in the fac
Shaun, what I’m trying to say is, I need something a little more. SHAUN offers her a Pork Scratching. She declines.
More than spending every night in the Winchester. I mean, I’m 29. (MORE )

I’ve got things I want to do with my life, I want to get out there, do more interesting stuff, live a little, but I’d love to be able to do it with you, but I want you to want to want to do it too. LIZ laughs grimly at her own silly sentence. She then tak pork scratching and regards SHAUN with a mixture of exasperation and affection.
I don’t want to go on at you, Jesus, listen to me. I’m beginning to sound like your Mum. Not that I’d know what she sounds like.
You still haven’t met his Mum?
Not Yet.
I can’t believe you haven’t met his mum.
It’s not that simple.
Don’t you get along with your Mum, Shaun?
It’s not that I don’t get along with her-
Are you ashamed of your Mum, Shaun?
No I’m not, I love my Mum.
(returning with drinks) I love his Mum.
Ed-
She’s butter.
Ed!
Shaun-
Shaun-
Guys-
Shaun-

Liz (holds up his hands) I totally understand what you’re saying and I agree, really I do. We should get out there. Do more interesting stuff. Together. We’1ll start tomorrow, I’1ll book a restaurant. The place that does all the fish. We’ll do it properly. Just the two of us. Things’1l change. Promise.
Really Shaun? The LANDLORD calls time. SHAUN stares back into space.
Shaun? The BELL rings again. The SPOOKY NOISES continue as...

A MONTAGE OF GREATER LONDON, Saturday 8 A.M. (All actions the sequence are choreographed to the TITLE MUSIC) ...A traffic jam. Drivers stare blankly ahead. A MIDDLE A MAN sits in a Jag wearing DRIVING GLOVES... ...A bus stop. BORED COMMUTERS ignore each other... ...A vast supermarket car park. Customers park up as a bo tied OLD MAN slowly collects discarded trolleys... ...A 24 hour supermarket serves earlybird customers. A va CHECKOUT GIRL bleeps products through her till...  ...A nightclub in an industrial estate expels its last patrons. DAZED YOUNG CLUBBERS wander into the daylight... ...A nondescript suburb. A BORED KID kicks a FOOTBALL aga a wall. We CLOSE IN on a semi-detached house...

Bare feet shuffle into shot. Slowly we PAN UP to see- SHAUN. Dead to the world. His face tired. He yawns. We are in the lounge. The decor is male, the room untidy. is sitting on the sofa, playing a video game. He may have been there all night. SHAUN sits next to him, picks up a game controller and presses a button. A VOICE booms.
Player two has entered the game.
Haven’t you got work? SHAUN puts the controller back down.
Player two has left the game.

A TOILET is flushed...a SHOWER run...TEETH brushed... SHAUN now wears a white short-sleeved shirt. He straighte his tie in the mirrored door of the bathroom cabinet, whi is ajar. He shuts it. PETE stands in the reflection. His face like thunder.
You do know the front door was open again last night?
A DRAWER is yanked open...A KNIFE grabbed...TOAST buttere BOTTLE OF MILK hits the table. PETE screws the lid on.
I’m not saying it was you.
I know man but-
I’m saying it was Ed.
Right. PETE returns the milk to its rightful place in the fridge also wears a shirt and tie, but is somewhat smarter.
I can’t live like this. Look at the state of it. We’re not students anymore.
Pete-
It’s not like he even brings any real money into the house.
He brings a bit.
What, dealing drugs?
Come on. He sells a bit of weed every now and again. You’ve sold puff.

Once! At college! To you! Anyway, I did a lot of stupid things at college Shaun. I dressed up as Frank N. Furter, I drank snakebite and black, I slept with a fat girl. Doesn’t mean I want to do any of them for a living.
Look I’ve known him since primary school. I like having him around. He’s a laugh.
What because he can impersonate an orangutan? Fuck-a-doodle-doo.
What?
He’s dead weight Shaun.
Oh leave him alone.
Okay, I admit, he can be pretty funny on occasion. I had a great time that night we sat up drinking Apple Schnapps and playing Tekken
Yeah, when was that?
Five years ago. When is he going home?
Whassup niggaz? ED enters and takes the milk from the fridge, he swigs fr the bottle and wanders out, scratching his nuts.
I’1l have a word.
SHAUN sits down by ED, who is again playing the video gam PETE watches at the door.
Hey man, listen...top left...
Thanks.
...I was just going to say...reload!
I’m on it.
...Since you’re...ooh nice shot.  10.
Thanks.
Since you’re in most of the day- ED’s mobile rings (ring tone: ‘HALLOWEEN’ ).
Two seconds. (answers ) Alright Noodle...No I only got an ‘enry. Shortage on...Alright. Laters. ED resumes his game. PETE’s seen enough and wades in.
Ed, since you’re not working at the moment, could you please clean up a bit?
I am working.
Since you are in the flat all the time do you think you could clean up a bit?
Yep.
And if you play the answer machine, could you take down everyone’s messages, not just your own?
Yep.
It’s not that taxing is it? Writing something on a ‘post-it’ note?

Nope. PETE’s mobile rings as he leaves (ring tone: ‘LIVE FOREVE by Oasis). He puts on his jacket. On the back is a ‘post- reading - ‘I AM A PRICK’ SHAUN sees this and shakes his head wearily at ED.  11.
Come on. It was pretty funny.
Seriously, will you do what he said?
I ain’t doing nothing for him.
Well, do it for me then.
(pauses game) I’m sorry Shaun.
It’s okay.
No, I’m sorry Shaun. SHAUN puzzles, before his expression turns to disgust.
Oh man that’s bad. You’re rotten. ED laughs. SHAUN does too, as he covers his nose and mout
I’1l stop doing them when you stop laughing.
I’m not laughing. I’m going. SHAUN leaves. The phone rings. The answer machine picks u
Hi, you’re through to Peter and Shaun. Please leave a message after the - Beep. PUSH IN as the RED LIGHT flashes.

Hello Shaun, it’s me. Look I’m going to be tied up a bit today, I've got twenty year ten essays to mark and I want to get them out of the way, so when you book the table, can you make it eight rather than seven? (MORE )
You’re probably not there anyway. I’ll try you at work. so...okay. Bye, bye. Bye. Bye. CLOSER. The RED LIGHT flashes. The screen is filled.
BANG. A FOOTBALL hits SHAUN in the head. He turns to see BORED KID grinning at him. He responds playfully.

Oh you’re dead! SHAUN boots the ball back. He walks past PETE in his car crosses the road. He heads for the newsagent passing a HOMELESS MAN in a green coat with a dog on a lead. He sta with an ARM OUTSTRETCHED. SHAUN gives him some change.
SHAUN grabs a coke from the fridge and goes to the counte

Nelson? There’s no-one there. SHAUN waits, idly scanning across t day's papers, their headlines partially concealed. ‘G.M. CROPS BLAMED FOR...’ ‘...UNIDENTIFIED MUTILATED...’ ‘,..SUPER-FLU...’ ‘...DOWNED SATELLITE CAUSES...’ SHAUN peers closer. As if by magic, the SHOPKEEPER appear
Hello my friend. No beer today?
Bit early for me. A PALE SUITED MAN enters hurriedly, as we follow SHAUN ou
Do you have any Aspirin?
Sold out.  13.
What! ?
Body on the line. SHAUN stands amid LIVID COMMUTERS. A POLICE CAR blazes pa

SHAUN is sat on a bus crowded with BLANK PASSENGERS; a PA GUY listens to his walkman, an OLD MAN slowly nods off. SHAUN looks out of the window. On the street, he sees a Y WOMAN faint. A number of PASSERS-BY rush to her aid. SHAUN’S VOICE (0.S.) Gather round everyone...
...gather round. Now as well as Mr. Sloman being off sick, I’m afraid Ash is also a bit under the weather, so I’m taking charge today, as I’m the...
Oldest.
...Senior staff member. We reveal a bunch of surly young SHOP ASSISTANTS chewing unison, in front of SHAUN. Among them, NOEL and DANNY.
I’m feeling under the weather, can I have the day off? A ripple of laughter. SHAUN tries to find it funny.
No, Ash genuinely is ill. So we’re going to have to pull together today- A mobile phone interrupts.  14.
Yeah? Hello mate.
Noel, could you-
Two seconds. NOEL holds up his hand. SHAUN concedes weakly.
Yeah man. I was totally munted. Yeah I spoke to him. He’s only got an ‘enry. SHAUN is left twiddling his red biro.
Alright man. Laters. (hangs up) Continue.
Thanks. As Mr. Sloman says, “there’s no ‘I’ in ‘team’ but there is an ‘I’ in ‘pie’...something about a team pie...I don’t know. That’s it- The ASSISTANTS are already off, ambling to their stations
Danny can you uh... DANNY is already opening the front doors...
And Sarah, will you um... SARAH is already switching on a bank of TV SCREENS...
Phone off please Noel. This isn’t a social gathering. SHAUN pockets his biro and tries to look officious.
Alright. Keep your hair on grandad.  15.
Hey, I’m only twenty nine for chrissakes. How old are you? Twenty? Twenty two?
Seventeen.
(thrown) Really?...Look Noel, I know you don’t want to be here forever. Neither do I. I got things I want to do with my life.
When? NOEL points to SHAUN’s top pocket. His biro has leaked.
You’ve got red on you.
SHAUN is demonstrating a TV to a young couple.

This one comes with a digital package. You got your lifestyle channels... FLIP. We see a clip of MOANING COUPLES on ‘Trisha’. +.-you got your entertainment channels... FLIP. We see a LAME GAME SHOW with contestants in funny costumes. An unseen commentator laughs uncontrollably. ...you got your news channels... FLIP. We see images of a CRASH SITE. People in WHITE SUIT

head_text.subj: GRAVE LOOKING SCIENTIST. A DISTRAUGHT VOX POP. A CONVOY O

text: MILITARY TRUCKS, RED LIGHTS flash. SHAUN stops flipping.
Shaun!
I’m with a customer.  16.

It’s your Dad! SHAUN looks to the counter. With NOEL is a MIDDLE-AGED MA SHAUN apologises to his customers and goes over. PHILIP is a greying bear of a man. He wears DRIVING GLOVE and makes only cursory eye contact with SHAUN.
Philip.
Shaun. I trust you haven’t forgotten about tomorrow?
Your bi-monthly visit.
I haven’t forgotten.
You could bring the flowers you forgot to send Barbara on Mother’s Day.
Yeah, I was gonna.
And not a cheap posy from a garage forecourt.
I wasn’t gonna.
The Texaco.
Alright!

Well, we'll look forward to seeing you tomorrow then. They glare at each other, before PHILIP heads for the doo SHAUN watches him leave, noticing another CONVOY OF MILIT TRUCKS on the street, RED LIGHTS flashing.  17.
Thought this wasn’t a social gathering.
What?
How come you’re allowed to talk to your Dad?
Look, A) he is not my Dad, he’s my stepdad and B) it was an emergency.
What, buying your Mum some flowers?
...Yes. NOEL grins to some nearby ASSISTANTS who snigger.
Look Noel, whatever you might think, I don’t find it difficult to keep my work and my social life separate. The phone rings. DANNY answers.
Shaun, Liz for you. SHAUN takes it, adopting a businesslike tone.
Hello.
Allo, it’s me.
Allo.
Just quickly, d’you get my message? SHAUN sees that NOEL and the other ASSISTANTS are watchin
Yep.  18.
So it’s all okay then?
Yep.
Eight instead of seven?
Yep. SHAUN fakes a yawn and makes a ‘wrap it up’ signal.
Okay cool, well, ring me later.
Goodbye Liz.
Bye. SHAUN hangs up and turns to NOEL and the others.
Liz. Head office. Nothing to panic about.
A DISTRESSED BUSINESSMAN, crying loudly, runs past the wi of a florist. Inside, SHAUN watches him go.
Sir?
Sorry, yeah, they’re for my Mum. The FLORIST produces some tags.
‘To a Wonderful Mum’ or ‘POW! Super Mum’.

Um...first one. SHAUN writes out the card and hands it back. He looks bac the street. On the other side of the road is a SCRUFFY MA the steps of a CHURCH, surrounded by pigeons.  19. SHAUN watches as the SCRUFFY MAN swipes at the pigeons. Amazingly he catches one. SHAUN’s transfixed as the SCRUFFY MAN raises the pigeon t his mouth. Surely he isn’t going to... A BUS pulls up outside. SHAUN cranes to see through the windows. When the bus pulls away, the SCRUFFY MAN is gone COMMUTER’S VOICE (0.S.) What the hell’s going on?
SHAUN is again amid a crowd of PISSED OFF COMMUTERS.
Bodies on the line. Suicides.
Suicide?
Suicides. Three. The GUARD raises three fingers. SHAUN is a little freaked
SHAUN is again on a bus crowded with BLANK PASSENGERS. Th man next to SHAUN coughs badly. The lady in front seems t have nodded off and is dribbling. The bus is barely movin
SHAUN walks. Cars honk, a traffic jam clogging up the roa He looks ahead to the cause, a CAR has stalled at the lig A HAND slaps SHAUN on the arm.
Ohmigod, Shaun!
Yvonne? YVONNE is in her late twenties. She’s jovial and short. S and SHAUN embrace, slightly awkwardly.
How you doing?  20.
Surviving.
Haven’t seen you since the days of... YVONNE mouths a house beat and does a little dance. SHAUN nods. A CROWD starts to gather around the stalled car.
Yep, good times.
You living round here?
Uh...yeah. You?
Yeah, I’ve just bought a place.
Bought? MORE PEOPLE gather around the CAR.
Bit grown up eh? You still with...
Liz. Yeah.
That’s great. She still teaching? An AMBULANCE pulls up. The SIREN forces them to shout.
Uh...yeah. She’s Head of English now. Got fast- tracked.
Ooh wow. What about you? Last time I saw you, you were working at that bloody electrical place.
Yeah... YVONNE clocks his name-tag and realises her faux pas.
You still deejaying?  21.
Not really. Kinda let it go, y'know? The SIREN wails on. YVONNE nods.
That’s a shame. Well, least you and Liz are still together. Glad somebody made it. How long’s it been now?
Four years. Last week actually.
Aw, did you doing anything special?
No, we’re going for a meal tonight.
Ooh, anywhere nice? The SIREN slows. Realisation dawns. SHAUN goes ashen-face
FRONT DOOR swung open...FLOWERS thrown into the sink...YE PAGES flung open. We see on the page: ‘Fulci’s. The place that does all the fish’. SHAUN anxiously paces on the phone. ED plays his videogam
You gonna thank me then?
What for?
Tidying up.
Doesn’t look that tidy.
Well, I had a few beers when I finished. The phone picks up at the other end.  22.
Fulci’s. Can you hold, please?
You want your messages?
What? ED produces a scrap of paper and reads aloud.
Your Mum phoned about you going round tomorrow. Liz phoned about you guys eating out tonight. Then your Mum phoned again to see if I wanted to eat her out tonight.
Hello?
Look, I know it’s short notice, but do you have a table for two for tonight?
Sorry, we just gave away the last table. CLICK. The line goes dead.
Aw, man! A beat.
That wasn’t true about your Mum. SHAUN stares at the receiver, deep in thought.
So, what are we going to do then? Where are we going to go?
The Winchester?
Don’t be so stupid! They don’t do food.  23.
John’1l do you a toastie. There’s a Breville out the back.
Ed, this is serious! SHAUN slams the phone down, it rings. He picks up.
Hello?
Aollo.
(caught out) ..-Allo...
So what’s the plan then?
Yeah, uh...babe, there’s been a bit of a problem with the table.
What do you mean?
They’re full up.
But you said it was all okay.
Yeah...
You didn’t book it did you?
No...
So what is the plan then? Silence. ED looks at SHAUN. He raises his eyebrows and no
(tentatively) We could go to...The Winchester?  24. SHAUN winces. CLICK. The phone goes dead. The YELLOW PAGES hits the floor...The FLOWERS are grabbed The FRONT DOOR is swung wide...
...A TAXI CAB DOOR slams shut. SHAUN sits anxiously in th back of the cab, feigning interest in the DRIVER’s waffle
...so he starts reaching through the window and moaning at me and I can’t understand what’s he’s bloody goin’ on about, so I drives off. Bedlam!
The CAB screeches off. SHAUN runs with the flowers across grass forecourt of an apartment block. He reaches the fro door and slams the intercom buzzer for LIZ’s flat.
Hello.
Dianne. Let me in please.
I’m not sure this is the best time Shaun.
Oh come on!
Lizzy doesn’t want to see you, Shaun.
Just open the door!
She doesn’t want to see you. Furious, SHAUN looks up to the FIRST FLOOR WINDOW.  25.
What do you want me to do? Do you want me to climb up the drainpipe and come through the window? Because I will.
A worried DAVID and DIANNE stand by the entry phone, in t coats. Behind, LIZ emerges, also preparing to go out.
Alright then. There are noises from outside. All look to the OPEN WINDO BUZZ. The entry phone again.
Guys? Let me in. Please. INT. LIZ’S BATHROOM -MOMENTS LATER A furious LIZ busies herself, getting ready to go out. SHAUN flits around her.
Liz, I can explain. Let’s just go out.
What, to the Winchester?
Do you want to?

Hmm, let me see. Liz, let’s have a quiet one in the Winchester. Liz, it’s Saturday night. Winchester night. Hey Liz, there’s a quiz on this evening. Really? Aw, I love a good quiz. Well, do you want to come? Yeah, where’s it on? THE WINCHESTER! No, I don’t fucking want to!
Sorry, I just thought we could-  26.
It’s not the only place in the world Shaun!
I know, we can go somewhere else.
DAVID and DAVID and DI sit on the sofa, listening through the wall.
I’m going out with David and Di.
Well, let’s all go together.
What, you hang out with a bunch of teachers? Sorry, a failed actress and a twat? DI look at each other, affronted.
Hey, that’s a bit harsh.
Your words.
I did not call Dianne a failed actress.
Cuh! DIANNE is relieved. DAVID remains affronted. LIZ storms i the lounge, with SHAUN in tow, helping her with her coat.
Seriously, let’s go out somewhere, forget all this. We’ll have a laugh, just the two of us. Things’1l be cool. Promise. LIZ turns angrily on SHAUN, who cowers behind the coat.
Oh stop making these promises!
What do you mean?  27.

Off the top of my head? You promised you'd stop smoking when I did. You promised you'd go back to the gym. You promised we’d go flat hunting. You promised you’d start deejaying again. You promised you'd try drinking red wine instead of beer. You promised you’d come on holiday with me. You-
We went to Greece didn’t we?
We met in Greece.
(disdainfully) At a rave.
It’s not the same. You promised things would change.
You promised you'd get us free cable.
I’m working on that!
Okay.
(to Liz) Well, look...I can stop smoking. I can give up whenever I want. See? SHAUN takes out a fag packet and chucks them in the bin.
What was the next one?
It’s not enough, Shaun. LIZ walks out, leaving SHAUN with DAVID and DI.
Basically, I think your nine lives are up-  28.
Oh get fucked four-eyes! Why don’t you go out with her, you love her so much? DAVID goes red.
I don’t know what you mean by that. SHAUN makes a ‘like you don’t know’ face and leaves.
I don’t know what he means by that. DIANNE says nothing. INT. LIZ’S ROOM -CONTINUOUS LIZ is sat on her bed. Head in her hands. SHAUN enters.
Got you these. He offers her the flowers with a smile. LIZ clocks the ta
“To A Wonderful Mum”?
Yeah...cos, remember last night, you said you didn’t want to sound like my Mum... LIZ laughs, more out of exasperation than amusment. A pau
They are for your Mum aren’t they?
Yep.
Smooth. LIZ returns her head to her hands.
Sorry. I wasn’t thinking. I’m tired.  29.
You're tired? It’s not the strongest defence is it? I’m tired Shaun.
Sorry.
The ‘S’ word again.
Sor...
You can’t just keep saying ‘sorry’ and expect things to be okay. You wave it around like a ‘get out of jail free’ card.
But, what if I am sorry?

What if you are? It’s not like you ever do anything about it. Nothing ever changes. (she sighs) Look, I’ve got to do something. If I don’t, I’m going to end up in that pub, every night for the rest of my life, like those other sad old fuckers, drinking myself to death, wondering what the hell happened.
What do you mean “do something”?
SLAM. SHAUN is stood outside. Still in his work clothes. Still holding the flowers. Face like... THUNDER. Rain falls. SHAUN stares blankly ahead.
SHAUN walks toward the pub, still holding the flowers. He sees a SNOGGING COUPLE in the shadows. He throws the flow into a NEARBY BIN.  30.
Shauny...

...hog lumps! A packet of PORK SCRATCHINGS hits a glum SHAUN in the fac cheery ED joins him at their usual table. Behind, a wall mounted TV shows a SQUAD CAR whizzing thro suburbs, lights flashing. Seconds later, the pub is illuminated by the FLASHING LIGHTS of a passing squad car

Fuck her. You got your pint. You got your pig snacks. What more d’you want? Your favorite monkey don’t you? You want me to do Clyde? ED proceeds to ape Clyde the orangutan from ‘Every Which But Loose’. SHAUN looks at him, bereft.
See I knew you’d get over her.
‘It’s been 7 hours and 15 days...’ ‘Nothing Compares 2 U’ starts up on the JUKEBOX.
Who the hell put this on?
It’s on random.
Oh for fuck’s sake! John? ED motions to JOHN for another round.

...CURTAINS ARE DRAWN...DEAD BOLTS click into place...The FRUIT MACHINE and JUKEBOX are switched off. SHAUN and ED now among the last customers and are utterly pissed. ED ignites two SAMBUCA shots. He and SHAUN ritualistically d them, spluttering and laughing.  31.
You know what we should do tomorrow? A hand appears on ED’s shoulder.
Keep it down a bit lads.
Sorry John. JOHN moves off with their empties. ED continues quietly.

You know what we should do tomorrow? Keep drinking. Have a Bloody Mary first thing. Get a bite at The King’s Head. Grab a couple at The Little Princess, stagger back here and bang! We’re up at the bar for shots. How’s that for a slice of fried gold? SHAUN remains utterly glum. ED (CONT’D) C’mon man talk to me.
Can we just leave it Ed?
What did she say?
A lot.
What a bitch.
She said if she stayed with me, she was going to end up sitting in here every night for the rest of her life like these sad old fuckers, drinking herself to death, wondering what the hell happened.
That’s harsh. These are not sad old fuckers. These are rich, interesting characters.  32. Cut away to a number of SAD OLD FUCKERS around the bar.
Like who? ED points to a MULLET HAIRED FIFTYSOMETHING at the bar.
Snakehips. Always surrounded by women. Bigamist. Strangled his first wife with a draft excluder. Invented the mobile disco. Vaguely amused, SHAUN points to an IRISH SPINSTER necking whisky.
What about her?
Ex-porn star. Done it all. Mish, doggy, reverse cowgirl, A2M. Starred in the world’s first interracial hardcore loop. Cafe au lait.
What about John?
Who, the “Barrel”? North London Mafia. SHAUN laughs and shakes his head.
That really is true. Big Al says so.
Big Al also says dogs can’t look up.
Think about it. The gruff demeanor. Handy with a blade. Bernie, the trophy wife. ED points to BERNIE, the wizened landlady behind the bar.
He’s connected. Why d’you think there’s a rifle over the bar?  33. ED nods to a rifle mounted on a brace.
‘Cos the pub’s called the Winchester.
Exactly. SHAUN lets himself laugh. ED smiles.
See, you don’t need Liz to have a good time.
Ed! Let’s just leave it now.

Listen, can I just say one thing? And I’m not gonna say, ‘there’s plenty more fish in the sea’. I’m not gonna say, ‘if you love her let her go’...I’m not gonna bombard you with cliches.
